facts.text: Appellant is a saw-mill carrying on business in Kozhikode in the State of Kerala.
Sankaran was in the employ of the appellant as a crosscutter.

On June 21, 1958, Sankaran came drunk to the mill and abused the Engineer, the Secretary and others and threatened them with physical violence. He was caught hold of by other workmen and taken outside.
Sankaran came again a short time later at 4:30 p.m. on June 21, 1958 and abused the same persons again.
Sankaran admitted that he had come to the mill at the relevant time for taking his wages for that week.

On June 24, 1958, appellant served a charge-sheet on Sankaran setting out the above facts and asked him to show cause why his services should not be terminated on account of his grave indiscipline and misconduct.
Sankaran gave an explanation the same day denying the allegations of fact made against him.
On June 25, 1958, Sankaran was informed that in view of his denial, a departmental inquiry would be held and he was also placed under suspension pending inquiry.
On June 25, 1958, Sankaran protested against his suspension and requested that in any case the departmental inquiry should be expedited.
As no inquiry was held till July 2, 1958, Sankaran again wrote to the appellant to hold the inquiry as early as possible.
On July 8, 1958, the appellant terminated the services of Sankaran under r. 18(a) of the Standing Orders without holding any departmental inquiry.

In the termination order of July 8, 1958, appellant informed Sankaran that the proposed inquiry, if conducted, would lead to further friction and deterioration in the rank and file of the employees in general and also that maintenance of discipline in the undertaking would be prejudiced if he was retained in service.
A dispute was raised by the union which was referred to the Industrial Tribunal, Kozhikode in I.D. No. 89 of 1958 by the Government of Kerala in October 1958.
Industrial Tribunal Award dated March 10, 1959: Something seemed to have happened on the afternoon of June 21, 1958 but there was no evidence to prove what had actually happened.
Tribunal held that appellant had intended to take disciplinary action but subsequently dropped proceedings and took action under r. 18(a); this was a colourable exercise of power.
No attempt made before tribunal to defend action under r. 18(a) by proving misconduct; two witnesses produced but key witnesses (Engineer, Secretary) not produced, no explanation.
Tribunal set aside the order of discharge and ordered reinstatement of Sankaran.
Appellant applied for special leave, which was granted.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant is entitled under r. 18(a) of the Standing Orders to terminate the services of Sankaran by giving 14 days notice or paying 12 days wages without any inquiry or justification, or whether such termination must be bona fide and not a colourable exercise of power.
Whether industrial tribunals can scrutinize terminations under r. 18(a) for bona fides, victimisation or unfair labour practice even if contractual.

petitioner_arguments.text: Entitled under r. 18(a) of the Standing Orders to dispense with the service of any employee after complying with its terms (14 days notice or 12 days wages), without holding inquiry or assigning reason.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: r. 18(a) of Standing Orders; Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India

petitioner_arguments.text: Having taken action under r. 18(a), no need to justify before tribunal; motive irrelevant if right exists under contract.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India; Patna Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Bali Rai

respondent_arguments.text: Termination under r. 18(a) was colourable exercise of power, as disciplinary action for misconduct was intended but dropped to avoid inquiry.
No evidence before tribunal to prove misconduct; key witnesses not produced.

court_reasoning.text: Claim to terminate under r. 18(a) without reason amounts to hire and fire at will, negating security of service secured through industrial adjudication.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot accept absolute right under contract; subject to industrial adjudication.

court_reasoning.text: Even under r. 18(a), termination must be bona fide; if colourable, victimisation or unfair labour practice, tribunal can intervene. Approves Labour Appellate Tribunal in Buckingham case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dropping intended misconduct inquiry and using r. 18(a) is colourable.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant could defend before tribunal by proving misconduct but failed; only two witnesses, key ones withheld.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal correctly did not accept evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Parshotam Lal Dhingra applies to government servants under Arts. 310, 311; different for industrial employees.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Contractual rights subject to industrial adjudication.

court_reasoning.text: Patna Electric case under s.33; present under s.10, different considerations.

holdings.text: Termination under r. 18(a) must be bona fide and not colourable; industrial court can inquire into causes and set aside if mala fide or unfair.
In this case, exercise of power under r. 18(a) was colourable; tribunal's view correct; appellant failed to justify.

precedents_cited.case_name: Buckingham and Carnatic Co. Ltd. v. Workers of the Company etc.
precedents_cited.relevance: Labour Appellate Tribunal held bona fides required even for termination by notice; capricious action evidence of victimisation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chartered Bank, Bombay v. Chartered Bank Employees Union
precedents_cited.relevance: Approved LAT observations on bona fides in terminations by notice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Assam Oil Company v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Approved LAT observations on bona fides in terminations by notice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Applies to government servants under Arts. 310/311; motive irrelevant if contractual right, but different for industrial employees.

precedents_cited.case_name: Srinivas Ganesh v. Union of India
Patna Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Bali Rai
precedents_cited.relevance: Dealt with s.33 Industrial Disputes Act; inapplicable to adjudication under s.10.

statutes_cited.name: Standing Orders
statutes_cited.relevance: r.18(a) allows termination by notice/pay for permanent workmen; r.21 for misconduct; power under 18(a) subject to bona fides scrutiny.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference under s.10 for adjudication; s.33 considerations different.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the Industrial Tribunal's award setting aside the termination of Sankaran's services under r.18(a) as a colourable exercise of power, and ordered reinstatement. The appeal by special leave was dismissed.

key_quotes.text: it is too late in the day for an employer to raise such a claim for it amounts to a claim to hire and fire an employee as the employer pleases and thus completely negatives security of service
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects absolute contractual right to terminate.

key_quotes.text: if the termination of service is a colourable exercise of the power or as a result of victimisation or unfair labour practice the industrial tribunal would have the jurisdiction to intervene
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of tribunal scrutiny under termination clauses.

key_quotes.text: the position of government servants stands on an entirely different footing as compared to industrial employees
key_quotes.speaker: court
